Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a laser scanning confocal microscope for cellular imaging for faculty and students at Baruch College
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Baruch College, City University of New York to provide support for the acquisition of an advanced confocal microscopy system with super-resolution capacity. The new system will support the current and foreseeable critical research needs of the faculty in the Department of Natural Sciences, which include multi-color imaging of fixed and live samples, time-lapse imaging, quantitative fluorescence, photo-activation, visualization of subcellular structures and organelles, spectral analysis of bioluminescent organisms, 3-D rendering and imaging of complex tissues. The system's versatility makes it capable of accommodating a wide variety of experimental approaches now and in the future and will maximize the number of researchers at Baruch who can use the new equipment for years to come. In addition to faculty research, the confocal will also be used to train graduate and undergraduate students in modern research practices and technologies as part of individually mentored research and classroom instruction.

The new confocal imaging system will be used by at least nine research groups within the Department of Natural Sciences and their collaborators, whose broad and multidisciplinary research objectives include the determination of hormone signaling mechanisms, elucidation of the role of reactive oxygen species in the nervous system, identification of bioluminescence in marine organisms, investigation of melanin in fungal pathogenesis, determination of muscle attachment site selection, elucidation of gene regulatory pathways governing vertebrate differentiation, identification of environmental impacts on insect behavior, and classification of morphological characteristics in speciation. These data will be publicized in the form of peer-reviewed publications and presentations at scientific meetings, as well as directly shared with interested researchers and collaborators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was the acquisition of a laser scanning confocal imaging system and an additional workstation for image processing equipped with three-dimensional image rendering software to enhance the research environment at Baruch College. Confocal microscopy is an essential tool for molecular, cellular and developmental biological research and a critical component for the expansion of faculty research programs at Baruch. An additional objective was to provide our diverse group of undergraduate students access, training and experience with confocal microscope technology. The microscope was acquired and set up as part of a shared imaging facility with the support of the Weissman School of Arts and Sciences, greatly enhancing the research infrastructure at Baruch. The impact on the Natural Sciences department and Biological Sciences major has been significant. The confocal microscope system has been used to generate data: examining the effects of reactive oxygen species on Drosophila neuromuscular junctions; visualizing mesodermal tissue migration throughout development; determining the effects of mutations on the formation of somatic muscle attachments to tendons; identifying hormone-expressing cells within the Drosophila larval central nervous system; and characterizing bioluminescence in marine organisms. This data has empowered faculty to develop and submit grant applications to federal agencies and to train research associates and graduate students. It has contributed to the tenure and promotion of diverse faculty members. Taking advantage of Baruch's unique position as an urban college and Hispanic-serving institution, we have provided access to this state-of-the-art technology to students from underrepresented backgrounds. Over 50 undergraduate students have taken a laboratory course where they learned how to use the confocal microscope system to generate and analyze their data examining gene expression patterns and cytoskeletal defects. Additional students performing independent work with faculty supervisors have used confocal data in their Honors Theses and have presented their work to their peers at Baruch and at other conferences. The acquisition of the confocal system has had a positive impact on Baruch's diverse student body by providing them with skills and experience to pursue STEM careers.
